original_data.question: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lb) over the last 4 months. She has recently avoided drinking alcohol and eating spicy food because it worsens her diarrhea and causes episodes of heart palpitations and reddening of the face and neck. She takes lisinopril for hypertension. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 149/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies show an increased urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely show which of the following?

model_response:
The patient has the carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by increased levels of 5-hydroxyindolacetic acid. The syndrome occurs in 67% of patients with carcinoid tumors. The most common site of origin for these tumors is the appendix. The syndrome is caused by vasoactive substances (e.g., serotonin) produced by the tumors. The syndrome is characterized by attacks of flushing, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and bronchospasm. Cardiac involvement can include endocardial fibrosis, pulmonary stenosis, and tricuspid insufficiency. The diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating increased urinary excretion of 5-hydroxyindolacetic acid.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
The state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.
An involuntary muscular contraction involving a muscle of the abdomen or of a hollow organ within the abdomen.
Decrease in existing BODY WEIGHT.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Behaviors associated with the ingesting of ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES, including social drinking.
The consumption of edible substances.
Substances taken in by the body to provide nourishment.

An increased liquidity or decreased consistency of FECES, such as running stool. Fecal consistency is related to the ratio of water-holding capacity of insoluble solids to total water, rather than the amount of water present. Diarrhea is not hyperdefecation or increased fecal weight.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.
An unpleasant sensation of irregular and/or forceful beating of the heart.
A transient reddening of the face that may be due to fever, certain drugs, exertion, or stress.
The anterior portion of the head that includes the skin, muscles, and structures of the forehead, eyes, nose, mouth, cheeks, and jaw.
The part of a human or animal body connecting the HEAD to the rest of the body.

Persistently high systemic arterial BLOOD PRESSURE. Based on multiple readings (BLOOD PRESSURE DETERMINATION), hypertension is currently defined as when SYSTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently greater than 140 mm Hg or when DIASTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently 90 mm Hg or more.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Lacking in hardness relatively or comparatively.
A dull achy pain.
Application of fingers with light pressure to the surface of the body to determine consistence of parts beneath in physical diagnosis; includes palpation for determining the outlines of organs.
Liquid by-product of excretion produced in the kidneys, temporarily stored in the bladder until discharge through the URETHRA.
The act or process of concentrating, focusing the attention and mental energy on a single object to the exclusion of others.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
